prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: M83Bar
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do a ~245"x90" mosaic on the stellar bar of the galaxy M83 in CO(2-1) and other lines. The target resolution is 1" to resolve GMCs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.14 K for dV=5 km/s. This dV is for 10-20pc clouds on the GMC size-line width relation. This sensitivity is to make ten sigma detection of H2 surface density of 30 Msun/pc^2 in a 5 km/s channel for alpha_co2-1=4.0 Msun/pc^2 (K km/s)^-1. The surface density is >~ 3-5 times lower than the typical mean surface density of GMCs in our Galaxy and hence is appropriate. For GMC studies that need cloud parameter fitting, 10 sigma is the 'minimum' detection. Also, to determine the mean of a distribution (of mass surface density, for example) one needs to securely 'detect' [in the sense of GMC studies] clouds whose mean surface densities are below the typical value.) Note that the peak line flux density of ~30 K ~ 500 mJy given in the field setup is for the brightest parts of the galaxy (nucleus, arms, etc.) while isolated GMCs in the disk will have much lower peak line flux (a few to 5 K).

The line width of 400 km/s is for the entire galaxy. Individual GMCs, in praticular the ones closer to our beam size, should have a small full line width of 5-10 km/s, hence we need the 1.5 km/s resolution to measure the line width and line shape.

We use 2-channel averaging to halve the data rate. Further averaing will not satisfy our scientific need to determine the line width and profile of ~5-10 km/s features (i.e., individual GMCs). Also, we use four spectral windows with the same spectral resolution because we have CO(2-1) in BB1, H30-alpha in BB2, CS(5-4) in BB3, and CH3OH in BB4. We may well detect more lines in particular from regions with high gas column densities such as the nucleus, bar-end, and spiral arms. Considering how expensive ALMA time is, we prefer to preserve their velocity information at a resolution comparable to that for CO even though we may later smooth the data.

The angular resolution of 1" (20pc) is to resolve and measure the size/mass distribution of ~50 pc giant molecular clouds. The largest scale of 100" is expected from single-dish observations (i.e., size in the channel maps of the entire galaxy). We need 7-m array and TP-array, as suggested by the OT.
Note: For the field mapped in this SG alone, we have a cycle 2 program in the same spectrometer setup at a higher angular resolution and five times lower T_b sensitivity. While the 12m array would only minimally contribute to this project when combined, the ACA data could reduce the need for our ACA use. We will consult the ARC/JAO staff in Phase 2.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: M83SE-arm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do a ~245"x90" mosaic around the SE arm of the galaxy M83 in CO(2-1) and other lines. The target resolution is 1" to resolve GMCs.

This sensitivity is to make ten sigma detection of H2 surface density of 30 Msun/pc^2 in a 5 km/s channel for alpha_co2-1=4.0 Msun/pc^2 (K km/s)^-1. The surface density is >~ 3-5 times lower than the typical mean surface density of GMCs in our Galaxy and hence is appropriate. For GMC studies that need cloud parameter fitting, 10 sigma is the 'minimum' detection. Also, to determine the mean of a distribution (of mass surface density, for example) one needs to securely 'detect' [in the sense of GMC studies] clouds whose mean surface densities are below the typical value.) Note that the peak line flux density of ~30 K ~ 500 mJy given in the field setup is for the brightest parts of the galaxy (nucleus, arms, etc.) while isolated GMCs in the disk will have much lower peak line flux (a few to 5 K).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose an arcsecond resolution imaging of molecular gas in the entire inner disk of M83 (30 square-kpc). We will study molecular gas and cloud properties, star formation, their interrelation as well as relation to gas dynamics. M83 is the nearest face-on grand-design spiral galaxy with a stellar bar. Our imaging area contains both of the spiral arms and the entire bar. We will resolve individual GMCs at 20 pc resolution and achieve 10-sigma mass sensitivity of 1e4 Msun for beam-size clouds. Statistical properties of the GMCs will be anlyzed as a function of gas dynamical environment (e.g., circumnuclear, on/off bar, bar-end, and on-/inter-arm). We will also quantify using HST data the association of GMCs to young star clusters and HII regions. Our central question is : How do galactic structures such as the bar and spiral arms affect the properties of GMCs and subsequent star formation? Our unprecedentedly detailed wide-area observations will allow a significant progress toward its answer. The data will also serve as a base for multi-wavelength studies of M83 by the community.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
